Tokyo Guidelines (TG13; adopted unchanged in TG18) define three grades:

- Grade III (severe): organ dysfunction in any one system—cardiovascular (hypotension needing dopamine >5 μg/kg/min or any norepinephrine), neurologic (decreased consciousness), respiratory (PaO2/FiO2 <300), renal (oliguria or creatinine >2.0 mg/dL), hepatic (PT-INR >1.5), hematologic (platelets <100,000/mm3).
- Grade II (moderate): any of WBC >18,000/μL; palpable tender RUQ mass; symptoms >72 h; marked local inflammation (gangrene, pericholecystic/hepatic abscess, biliary peritonitis, emphysematous cholecystitis).
- Grade I (mild): does not meet Grade II/III; no organ dysfunction; mild gallbladder inflammation. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3429769/?utm_source=openai))

Positive FAST = ultrasound evidence of free fluid.
Key findings (anechoic fluid):
- RUQ: Morison’s pouch (hepatorenal recess) or above the liver/right paracolic gutter.
- LUQ: around spleen (splenorenal recess), between spleen and diaphragm, or left paracolic gutter.
- Pelvis: posterior to bladder (rectovesical pouch) or posterior to uterus (pouch of Douglas).
- Cardiac view: pericardial effusion surrounding the heart (hemopericardium).

Extended FAST (not required for basic FAST) also considers hemothorax (pleural fluid) and pneumothorax signs (absent lung sliding/lung point). ([acep.org](https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/basic/fast?utm_source=openai))

Positive FAST = visualization of anechoic free fluid in any target space:
- Intraperitoneal: RUQ (Morison’s pouch/right paracolic gutter), LUQ (splenorenal/subphrenic), or pelvis (rectouterine/rectovesical). 
- Pericardial: pericardial effusion. 
Many centers use eFAST; additional positives are pleural fluid (hemothorax) or pneumothorax signs (absent lung sliding/barcode sign). ([acep.org](https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/basic/fast?utm_source=openai))

Positive FAST = visualization of anechoic free fluid in any dependent intraperitoneal space or an anechoic pericardial effusion on the standard windows. ([acep.org](https://www.acep.org/sonoguide/basic/fast))
Typical positive sites: RUQ hepatorenal recess/Morison’s pouch and right paracolic gutter; LUQ perisplenic/splenorenal or subphrenic; pelvis (rectovesical/rectouterine pouch of Douglas). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC3831800/?utm_source=openai))
Clotted blood may appear hypoechoic/heterogeneous yet still represents free fluid; even trace pelvic free fluid may be considered positive. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC8933745/?utm_source=openai))

Positive FAST = any sonographically detected free fluid in trauma-dependent spaces:
- RUQ: hepatorenal recess (Morison’s pouch), ± right paracolic gutter/subdiaphragmatic space
- LUQ: splenorenal recess, ± left subdiaphragmatic space
- Pelvis: rectouterine (pouch of Douglas) or rectovesical pouch
- Pericardial space: pericardial effusion on the subxiphoid/cardiac view

Fluid is typically anechoic (may become mixed echogenic as blood clots). In eFAST, pleural fluid (hemothorax) or pneumothorax signs are additional, but classic FAST focuses on peritoneal and pericardial fluid. ([ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK470479/?utm_source=openai))

Definition/clinical context: Pattern seen when chest pain has resolved, indicating critical proximal LAD stenosis and high short‑term risk of large anterior MI. Troponin may be normal or only slightly elevated. Avoid stress testing; urgent cardiology evaluation is warranted.

ECG (recorded in pain‑free state):
- Precordial leads V2–V3 (may extend V1–V6).
- Isoelectric or minimal ST elevation (<1 mm).
- No precordial Q waves; preserved R‑wave progression.
- T‑wave “pseudonormalization” may occur during pain.

Types:
- Type A (Type 1): Biphasic T waves with initial positivity and terminal negativity; ~25% of cases.
- Type B (Type 2): Deep, symmetric T‑wave inversion; ~75% of cases. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/sites/books/NBK482490/

Definition: A “pain-free” ECG pattern after recent angina that signifies critical proximal LAD ischemia.

Type A: Biphasic T waves (initial up, terminal down) in V2–V3; may extend across V1–V6.

Type B: Deep, symmetric T‑wave inversion in V2–V3; may extend across precordial leads.

Additional ECG/clinical features:
- Minimal or no ST deviation (typically <1 mm)
- No precordial Q waves and preserved R‑wave progression
- Pattern present when pain-free; troponin normal or only mildly elevated
- Highly specific for LAD disease; type A may evolve to type B

- Type A: biphasic T waves in V2–V3 (initial positive, terminal negative). 
- Type B: deep, symmetric T‑wave inversion in V2–V3 (may extend V1–V6). 
Clinical context/criteria: recent angina now pain‑free; ECG pattern present in pain‑free state; isoelectric or minimal ST elevation (<1 mm); preserved R‑wave progression; no precordial Q waves; normal or slightly elevated biomarkers; T waves may pseudonormalize during pain; indicates critical LAD stenosis with high risk of impending large anterior MI and need for urgent angiography. Wellens syndrome is a post-anginal, pain-free ECG pattern indicating critical proximal LAD disease. Type A: biphasic T waves in V2–V3 (initial positive, terminal negative). Type B: deep, symmetric T-wave inversion in V2–V3; changes may extend V1–V6. Typical accompanying features: little/no ST elevation (<1 mm), no precordial Q waves, preserved R-wave progression, and normal or mildly elevated biomarkers; during pain, T waves may pseudonormalize. Patients are at high risk of imminent anterior MI—avoid stress testing; arrange urgent cardiology and angiography. ([litfl.com](https://litfl.com/wellens-syndrome-ecg-library/?utm_source=openai))

Diagnostic criteria:

InterTAK Diagnostic Criteria (2018, preferred)
- Transient LV regional dysfunction (apical, midventricular, basal, or focal; often beyond one coronary territory; RV may be involved). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/?utm_source=openai))
- Physical/emotional trigger may occur; neurologic disease or pheochromocytoma can trigger. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/?utm_source=openai))
- New ECG changes (ST elevation/depression, T‑wave inversion, QTc prolongation). ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/?utm_source=openai))
- Modest troponin/CK rise; BNP often high. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/?utm_source=openai))
- CAD may coexist; exclude infectious myocarditis; usually affects postmenopausal women. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/?utm_source=openai))

Modified Mayo Clinic criteria (2008)
- Transient LV mid‑segment ± apical hypokinesis/akinesis beyond a single vascular territory.
- No obstructive CAD or acute plaque rupture.
- New ECG changes or modest troponin rise.
- Exclude pheochromocytoma and myocarditis. ([pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov](https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC6714036/?utm_source=openai))

Sources:
https://pmc.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/articles/PMC5991216/

The contemporary standard is the InterTAK Diagnostic Criteria (2018):
- Transient LV dysfunction with typical wall‑motion patterns (apical, midventricular, basal, or focal); RV may be involved; usually beyond one coronary territory.
- Trigger may be emotional or physical but is not required; neurologic disease or pheochromocytoma can trigger.
- New ECG changes (ST elevation/depression, T‑wave inversion, or QTc prolongation).
- Moderate troponin/CK rise; BNP commonly elevated.
- Significant coronary artery disease can coexist.
- No infectious myocarditis (cardiac MRI recommended to exclude).
- Predominant in post‑menopausal women. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))

Classic modified Mayo criteria (2008) emphasize transient wall‑motion abnormality beyond a single vascular territory, absence of obstructive CAD/acute plaque rupture, new ECG changes or modest troponin rise, and exclusion of pheochromocytoma or myocarditis. Diagnostic criteria (InterTAK, 2018) for takotsubo syndrome:
- Transient LV systolic dysfunction (apical, mid‑ventricular, basal, or focal variants); RV may be involved; wall‑motion pattern usually extends beyond a single epicardial territory. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))
- Emotional/physical trigger may occur but is not required; neurologic disease and pheochromocytoma can be triggers. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))
- New ECG changes (ST elevation/depression, T‑wave inversion, QTc prolongation) and modest troponin/CK rise; BNP often elevated. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))
- Significant CAD may coexist; diagnosis requires no culprit lesion explaining dysfunction. ([link.springer.com](https://link.springer.com/article/10.1007/s12574-020-00480-y?utm_source=openai))
- No evidence of infectious myocarditis (CMR recommended). ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))
- Predominantly affects postmenopausal women; function typically recovers. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))

Why these sources: The 2018 European Heart Journal international consensus established the InterTAK diagnostic criteria, and an ESC imaging consensus reproduces and clarifies them regarding coexistence with CAD. ([academic.oup.com](https://academic.oup.com/eurheartj/article/39/22/2032/5025412))
